pull.title: rpc: Fix data race (UB) in InterruptRPC()
pull.body:
Fix data race (UB) in `InterruptRPC()`.

Before:

```
$ ./configure --with-sanitizers=thread
$ make
$ test/functional/test_runner.py feature_shutdown.py
…
SUMMARY: ThreadSanitizer: data race rpc/server.cpp:314 in InterruptRPC()
…
ALL                 | ✖ Failed  | 2 s (accumulated)
```

After:

```
$ ./configure --with-sanitizers=thread
$ make
$ test/functional/test_runner.py feature_shutdown.py
…
ALL                 | ✓ Passed  | 3 s (accumulated)
```

events.body:
utACK 10f8244a777392f87c2671d743b14201d24351be

I don't think this can actually result in a data race but an atomic is certainly more appropriate here.

issue.title: travis: Enable functional tests in the ThreadSanitizer (TSan) build job
issue.body:
Enable functional tests in the ThreadSanitizer (TSan) build job.

This is a follow-up to @MarcoFalke's #14764 which added TSan but for unit tests only.

events.message: rpc: Fix data race (UB) in InterruptRPC()

events.body: I'm still getting `feature_shutdown.py` failures on Travis, see e.g. https://travis-ci.org/bitcoin/bitcoin/jobs/470997593#L3104
@Sjors that's fixed by #14958 which depends on #14982.

issue.title: tests: Running with --usecli ~5x slower than without
issue.body:
Bought up in IRC [here (line 603)](http://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/log-2019-01-31.html). More discussion [here (line 10)](http://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/log-2019-02-01.html).

master @ cb35f1d305d88934df64c2e7fb80700b673360e6
with `--usecli`:
```
test/functional/test_runner.py --usecli wallet_disableprivatekeys.py
Temporary test directory at /var/folders/z2/cn877pxd3czdfh47mfkmbwgm0000gn/T/test_runner_₿_🏃_20190201_113059
1/1 - wallet_disableprivatekeys.py passed, Duration: 35 s             

TEST                         | STATUS    | DURATION

wallet_disableprivatekeys.py | ✓ Passed  | 35 s

ALL                          | ✓ Passed  | 35 s (accumulated) 
Runtime: 35 s
```

without `--usecli`:
```
test/functional/test_runner.py wallet_disableprivatekeys.py
Temporary test directory at /var/folders/z2/cn877pxd3czdfh47mfkmbwgm0000gn/T/test_runner_₿_🏃_20190201_113144
1/1 - wallet_disableprivatekeys.py passed, Duration: 7 s

TEST                         | STATUS    | DURATION

wallet_disableprivatekeys.py | ✓ Passed  | 7 s

ALL                          | ✓ Passed  | 7 s (accumulated) 
Runtime: 7 s
```

issue.title: Bitcoin 0.18 locking PRs
issue.body:
These are locking changes from upstream (bitcoin core) release 0.18 (Aug 13, 2018, to Mar 3, 2019), oldest to newest (when merged to the master branch).

UPDATE 2021-May-4: This PR is complete, ready for review.

NOTE: This PR's branch is based on #5034, which hasn't merged yet, so its commits appear here also. For the current PR, please review only commit "Add missing locks and locking annotations for CAddrMan" and beyond (I will remove this comment before this PR gets merged.)

Each commit also includes a reference both to the PR and the upstream commit.

- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13115
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14444
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/11634
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13123
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14953
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14993
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12151
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12153
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15322
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15321
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15201
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15365

labels.name: C-upstream-port
labels.description: Category: Changes that are ported from the Bitcoin Core codebase.

labels.name: I-race
labels.description: Problems and improvements related to race conditions.

issue.title: Backports from Bitcoin
issue.body:
We recently investigated the Bitcoin issues which are related to privacy protection, vulnerability patches, or security enhancements. We have also checked the `repoName` source code. Results show that these issues and their PRs are not backported yet. Henceforth, we suggest that `repoName` should backport the PRs listed below for the considerations of software security and integrity. 

- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#17906](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17906), avoid uninitialized reads.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#16572](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16572), fix a `Char` variable used as `Bool`.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#15039](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15039), avoid leaking `nLockTime` fingerprint.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#14993](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14993), fix data race in `InterruptRPC()`.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13808](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13808), shuffle coins before grouping, for privacy protection.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13683](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13683), avoid potential null pointer dereference.

Some of these issues and PRs are not severe security-related, but backports can avoid the chaos ecosystem of Bitcoin-forked projects and the potential vulnerabilities in the future. 

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Backports from Bitcoin
issue.body:
We recently investigated the Bitcoin issues which are related to privacy protection, vulnerability patches, or security enhancements. We have also checked the `BTCGPU` source code. Results show that these issues and their PRs are not backported yet. Henceforth, we suggest that `BTCGPU` should backport the PRs listed below for the considerations of software security and integrity. 

- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#17906](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17906), avoid uninitialized reads.

- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#16251](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16251), improve `signrawtransaction` error reporting.

Some of these issues and PRs are not severe security-related, but backports can avoid the chaos ecosystem of Bitcoin-forked projects and the potential vulnerabilities in the future.

issue.title: Backports from Bitcoin
issue.body:
We recently investigated the Bitcoin issues which are related to privacy protection, vulnerability patches, or security enhancements. We have also checked the `zcash` source code. Results show that these issues and their PRs are not backported yet. Henceforth, we suggest that `zcash` should backport the PRs listed below for the considerations of software security and integrity. 

- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#17906](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17906), avoid uninitialized reads.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#16572](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16572), fix a `Char` variable used as `Bool`.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#15305](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15305), fix crash when disconnecting fail.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#15039](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15039), avoid leaking `nLockTime` fingerprint.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#14993](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14993), fix data race in `InterruptRPC()`.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13808](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13808), shuffle coins before grouping, for privacy protection.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13683](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13683), avoid potential null pointer dereference.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13907](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13907), avoid unlimited `locator` size in [link](https://github.com/zcash/zcash/blob/master/src/main.cpp#L6633).

Some of these issues and PRs are not severe security-related, but backports can avoid the chaos ecosystem of Bitcoin-forked projects and the potential vulnerabilities in the future. 

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

- [x] Bitcoin [PR#13808](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13808), shuffle coins before grouping, for privacy protection.

Some of these issues and PRs are not severe security-related, but backports can avoid the chaos ecosystem of Bitcoin-forked projects and the potential vulnerabilities in the future. 

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: [Backport] Backports from Bitcoin
issue.body:
We recently investigated the Bitcoin issues which are related to privacy protection, vulnerability patches, or security enhancements. We have also checked the `dgecoin` source code. Results show that these issues and their PRs are not backported yet. Henceforth, we suggest that `dogecoin` should backport the PRs listed below for the considerations of software security and integrity. 

- [x] Bitcoin [PR#17906](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17906), avoid uninitialized reads - #2759
- [x] Bitcoin [PR#16572](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16572), fix a `Char` variable used as `Bool` - #2765
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#16251](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16251), improve `signrawtransacAtion` error reporting.
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#15305](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15305), fix crash when disconnecting fail. - #2767
- [x] Bitcoin [PR#15039](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15039), avoid leaking `nLockTime` fingerprint. - #2756
- [x] Bitcoin [PR#14993](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14993), fix data race in `InterruptRPC()` - #2755
- [x] Bitcoin [PR#14728](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14728), fix uninitialized read - #2757
- [x] Bitcoin [PR#13907](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13907), introduce a maximum size for locators - #2758
- [ ] Bitcoin [PR#13808](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13808), shuffle coins before grouping, for privacy protection.
- ~~Bitcoin [PR#13683](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13683), avoid potential null pointer dereference.~~

Some of these issues and PRs are not severe security-related, but backports can avoid the chaos ecosystem of Bitcoin-forked projects and the potential vulnerabilities in the future. 

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

comments.body: This is the only change needed, why the other changes when there's assign and cast operators?
Could rename to `g_rpc_running` to clarify that it is a global?
